О зарубежном информационном воздействии на популярность отечественного  
нефтегазового образования  
(About foreign informational influence on the popularity of domestic oil and gas education) 
Семенова Ольга Михайловна1, Харитонов Дмитрий Николаевич2 
1,2Студент 
РГУ нефти и газа (НИУ) имени И.М. Губкина 
Научный руководитель: к.ф.н., доцент Душин А.В. 
 
АННОТАЦИЯ 
Нефтегазовый сектор занимает особое место в экономике России, являясь одной из 
самых конкурентных отраслей страны на мировом рынке. Поэтому информационная борьба 
западных стран объективно направлена на снижение конкурентоспособности не только 
нефтегазового сектора России, но и российского нефтегазового образования. Задачей работы 
является выявление методов возможного воздействия на молодежь с целью снижения престижа 
отечественного нефтегазового образования.  
 
ABSTRACT 
The oil and gas sector occupies a special place in the Russian economy, being one of the 
country's most competitive industries in the world market. Therefore, the information struggle of 
Western countries is objectively aimed at reducing the competitiveness of not only the oil and gas 
sector of Russia, but also the Russian oil and gas education. The task of the work is to identify 
methods of possible influence on young people in order to reduce the prestige of the domestic oil and 
gas education. 
 
КЛЮЧЕВЫЕ СЛОВА 
Информационное воздействие, конкурентоспособность, конкуренция на рынке труда, 
престиж отечественного нефтегазового образования. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Informational influence, competitiveness, competition in the labor market, prestige of domestic 
oil and gas education. 
 
Международная конкуренция в нефтегазовом секторе всегда носила острый характер. Во 
времена СССР советские специалисты нефтегазового профиля работали в нефтегазовых 
комплексах многих развивающихся стран и даже готовили там специалистов для местной 
промышленности. Усиление позиций России на мировом рынке углеводородов в последнее 
десятилетие усилило и конкуренцию в нефтегазовом образовании. Мы полагаем, что 
дальнейшая конкуренция в этой сфере будет направлена на снижение престижа получения 
нефтегазового образования в российских вузах. Для этого будет использован весь арсенал 
информационного воздействия на российскую молодежь, потенциальных абитуриентов.  
В ходе исследования мы обнаружили несколько способов возможного информационного 
воздействия, которые могут привести к снижению популярности нефтегазового образования в 
России. Во-первых, частые упоминания различными экспертами прогнозов о достаточно 
скором иссякании углеводородов могут негативно сказаться при выборе человеком будущей 
профессии. Например, еще 1919 году главный редактор американского журнала Geological 
Survey прогнозировал, что запасы нефти иссякнут в ближайшие 9 лет, а 1972 году 
американский аналитик Деннис Медоуз представил Римскому клубу свой знаменитый доклад 
«Пределы роста», обещая, что нефти скоро не будет [1]. Между тем, уже в 2003 году наша 
страна впервые вышла на первое место в списке производителей нефти, обогнав Саудовскую 
Аравию, 
что 
означает 
реальную 
востребованность 
отечественных 
специалистов 
и 
нефтегазового образования в России.  
Во-вторых, мы обратили внимание на то, что в зарубежных фильмах о нефтяной 
промышленности нефтегазовая отрасль связывается с негативными событиями: войнами, 
преступностью, техногенными или природными катастрофами [2]. Это также не добавляет 
желания получать нефтегазовое образование. Также снижение популярности нефтегазового 

429 
 
образования может вызываться искусственной популяризацией альтернативных сфер 
деятельности, например, сферы IT, куда может уходить наиболее талантливая молодежь, а 
также пропагандой легкого и быстрого заработка в социальных сетях. Нередко в западных 
СМИ звучат гиперболизированные обвинения России в загрязнении окружающей среды, а 
зачастую в списке стран-загрязнителей Россию ставят на первое место, что не соответствует 
действительности [3]. Однако это также не может не оказывать влияние на выбор молодежью 
специальности, особенно в условиях агрессивной популяризации экологических трендов.  
Между тем зарубежные вузы ведут активную компанию по привлечению абитуриентов в 
свои нефтегазовые вузы [4], а работодатели элементарно переманивают молодых 
отечественных специалистов нефтегазового профиля из других стран, в том числе и России, за 
рубеж. Обратим внимание и на то, что западные страны навязывают тренд «зеленой 
энергетики» [5], умалчивая о его недостатках и невозможности их краткосрочной реализации, 
критикуя нефтегазовую энергетику как «грязную» и неперспективную, что также может 
привести к падению популярности нефтегазового образования в России.  
Еще в VI—V веке до н. э. Сунь-Цзы говорил: «Если знаешь его и знаешь себя, сражайся 
хоть сто раз, опасности не будет; если знаешь себя, а его не знаешь, один раз победишь, другой 
раз потерпишь поражение; если не знаешь ни себя, ни его, каждый раз, когда будешь 
сражаться, будешь терпеть поражение» [5]. Конкурентная борьба в сфере нефтегазового 
образования является частью необъявленной войны за умы и таланты современной молодежи, в 
которой 
активно 
используются 
все 
современные 
информационные 
технологи, 
информационного 
воздействия, 
чтобы 
эффективно 
им 
противостоять, 
одновременно 
информируя молодежь поскольку ставки очень высоки.  Поэтому необходимо знать все 
технологии об отечественном нефтегазовом образовании, многократно доказавшем свой 
высочайший мировой уровень.

The issue of forecasting energy consumption  
Abramkin Gevorg Vladimirovich 
Student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas (National Research University) 
Supervisor: Senior Lecturer Orlova E.V. 
 
ABSTRACT 
This paper discusses the issue of predicting energy consumption by countries using 
natural gas consumption as an example. The paper is based on statistical data on natural gas 
imports in the Federal Republic of Germany. The study uses statistical methods such as 
correlation, factor, and regression analysis. The influence of different factors on natural gas 
consumption was examined. The data is considered for the period from 1976 to 2019. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Mathematical modelling, natural gas, regression analysis, forecasting, energy, 
development prospects.  
 
Forecasting natural gas consumption has long been an issue for countries around the 
world. The European Union has recently witnessed an energy crisis caused by the global 
energy transition and the abandonment of oil and coal consumption for power generation and 
heating. At the same time, natural gas has begun to play a huge role and its consumption is 
constantly increasing. An analysis of the international natural gas market shows a surge in 
demand for the energy resource at the beginning of autumn 2021. The most reliable 
forecasting method that can improve market stability is regression analysis [1]. 
From the results of statistical information processing, we derive a multiple regression 
equation for this model: Y = -256,9614 + 0,9774X1-0,01613X2-0,00523X3 + 3,8375X4 + 
0,1483X5 , where X1 - annual average temperature air, X2 - annual average rainfall, X3 - 
annual average sunshine hours, X4 - population, X5 - GDP. This equation describes 88.7% of 
imports. Of all the factors, only the GDP factor is confirmed as significant.  
Possible economic interpretation of the model: an increase of 1 oC in winter leads to an 
average decrease of imports by 0.641 bcm ; an increase of 1 oC in summer leads to an average 
increase of imports by 4.356 bcm ; an increase in population by 1 million leads to an increase 
in imports by 2.901 bcm on average; an increase in GDP by 10 billion dollars leads to an 
increase in imports by 0.151 bcm on average. 
When forecasting, the relative error was 12.2%, which may indicate other factors that 
affect gas imports. The calculated figure is 108.4 bcm in 2019, when it was 123 bcm. For this 
kind of model, the margin of error should be less than 20%. Overall, a country's economic 
well-being plays the most important role in the import model for natural gas. In Germany, for 
example, the level of GDP explains more than 80% of the variation in imports. The second 
most important factor is the demographic factor. The climate factor is not confirmed to be 
important, but summer temperature may be much more important than winter temperature. 
When considering the above factors, a robust mathematical model can be constructed. Based 
on a multiple regression equation, imports can be predicted point by point. 
 
REFERNCES: 
1. Draper N. R., Smith G., Applied Regression Analysis. New-York, John Wiley & sons, Inc, 
2014. 736 p.

Combating hydrogen sulfide: case of the Astrakhan gas condensate field 
Aliev Aliovsat 
Bachelor Student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas  
(National Research University)  
Scientific supervisor: Cand. of Sc. Igrevsky L.V. 
Academic adviser: Cand. of Sc., Assoc. Prof. Amitirova-Turgeneva D.L. 
 
ABSTRACT 
The purpose of the study is to analyze the new ways to reduce the development time 
and to lower costs of production at the Astrakhan gas condensate field. These issues arise 
because of high content of hydrogen sulfide in the extracted raw material. The following 
harmful effects were considered: toxicity, corrosion and air pollution. Despite the methods 
applied, the development of high-sulfur gas is still accompanied by great difficulties. The 
methods of combating H2S presented in the work can be applied in the production in oil and 
gas fields of Russia. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Hydrogen sulfide, gas condensate, toxicity, corrosion, air pollution. 
 
High concentration of hydrogen sulfide is a common problem in Russian gas fields. 
Astrakhan, Orenburg, Western Siberia and offshore fields use various methods to overcome 
this problem.  
Gas reserves at the Astrakhan field are estimated at 2.5 trillion m3, with current 
production of 12 million m3, the development of the field is planned until 2222. During 36 
years of commercial development, less than 10% of reserves have been extracted. These facts 
make it obvious that new methods of combating H2S have to be provided. 
Usually three harmful effects of hydrogen sulfide are distinguished: toxicity, corrosion 
of underground equipment and pipelines, air pollution. Since the content of H2S in the gas 
amounted up to 26%, the first factor implies the mandatory wearing of personal protective 
equipment: a protective helmet, technical rubber gloves, workwear to protect against general 
industrial pollution and static electricity and a gas mask. Besides, every employee has to 
attend a course of lectures followed by a check of knowledge of gas safety rules before he/she 
is allowed to enter the territory of the Astrakhan field. 
Sulfide stress corrosion cracking damages underground equipment and pipelines. The 
dissociation process of H2S goes in two stages (Equations 1 and 2):

Atomic hydrogen adsorbed on the surface of steel pipe can penetrate into the metal, 
which leads to its destruction. To prevent that problem, the inhibitor «Dodigen 4482-1c» is 
applied, which has the following advantages: 
• controllability of the corrosion rate reduction process; 
• the ability to slow down the corrosion destruction of pipelines that were in 
operation; 
• relatively low capital costs; 
• the possibility of simultaneous protection of almost all types of field 
equipment. 
As for air pollution, the production of hydrogen sulfide-containing natural gas by 
Gazprom Dobycha Astrakhan LLC is associated with emissions of pollutants that are part of 

434 
 
the extracted raw materials. For that issue, well blowing system is applied. It consists of a 
closed system of underground tanks and pipelines from the gas pretreatment unit straight to 
the refinery, bypassing other steps, which reduces the impact of harmful substances on the 
atmosphere. Moreover, there is a so-called "sanitary zone" around the enterprise. This is a 
zone, in which there are no settlements at a distance of 5 km from each well. Within its limits 
every employee should wear a gas mask. 
In conclusion, the problem of toxicity and destruction of pipelines at the Astrakhan 
field can be considered successfully solved. On the other hand, the company lacks modern 
technologies for detecting hydrogen sulfide emissions, which can pollute the air. For this task, 
an environmental monitoring system is used at the Orenburg field. Three mobile laboratories 
are patrolling and analyzing the air for the content of nine possible foreign substances in it 
(including H2S). Speaking of foreign experience, American companies ExxonMobil and 
Sceptre, Inc. have agreed to work together to deploy satellite technology for real-time 
detection of harmful substances in the oilfields and at a global scale.

Assessment of the technical and economic efficiency of hydraulic fracturing using FiberFrac 
technology by the method of correlation analysis of statistical geological and field data 
Imangulov Dinis Vadimovich1, Bikbauva Adel Ildarovna2 
1,2Student 
1,2Ufa State Oil Technical University Ufa State Petroleum Technological University 
Research Supervisor: Doctor of Economics, Mukhametshina G.S. 
 
ABSTRACT  
The main type of geological and technical measures in the oil fields of Western 
Siberia today is hydraulic fracturing. From the point of view of the financial component, 
hydraulic fracturing using the FiberFrac technology, like any other method of enhanced oil 
recovery, is an investment project aimed at making a profit by exporting additionally 
produced oil. Income from additionally produced oil does not always cover the capital costs 
of its implementation. From here it follows that in addition to the technological effect of this 
operation, it is necessary to take into account its economic profitability. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Hydraulic fracturing, FiberFrac, cross-linked gel, technical and economic efficiency, 
cost-effective production, limiting the growth of a hydraulic fracture in height. 
 
In 2020-2021, the share of hydraulic fracturing (HF) in the oil fields of Western 
Siberia amounted to 48.1% (569 out of 1183 well operations). The widespread use of this 
operation is based on its main advantage associated with an immediate increase in well 
production rate due to a significant increase in the permeability of the bottomhole formation 
zone (BHP) due to the creation of a developed system of cracks and microcracks. However, 
hydraulic fracturing has a number of significant drawbacks due to clogging of the bottomhole 
zone with proppant and products of chemical reactions, as well as premature watering of the 
produced product. 
In this regard, there is a need to improve this geological and technical measure 
(GTM). The most proven of the latest methods to improve the efficiency of hydraulic 
fracturing is the FiberFrac technology, which consists in adding a crosslinking agent to the 
hydraulic fluid. 
When this reagent is added to the hydraulic fracturing fluid, a cross-linked gel is 
created - a solution with a developed internal structure, which prevents the proppant from 
settling under the action of gravitational forces, which significantly improves the sand-
carrying properties of the sand-carrying fluid, thereby ensuring the opening of the fracture to 
its entire half-length and preventing clogging of the pore channels by the proppant in the PPP. 
The essence of the method is to plot the technical and economic efficiency of 
geological and technical operations. To do this, the value of one of the geological and 
physical parameters (permeability, porosity, effective reservoir thickness, net-to-gross ratio 
and oil saturation) is plotted on the abscissa axis, and the cumulative oil production for the 
reporting period is plotted on the ordinate axis. Points corresponding to the given values for 
each well are put on the obtained coordinate plane. After that, a trend line is built for the 
obtained points, and the line type is chosen so that the value of the approximation reliability is 
as close as possible to unity. The dependence obtained is adapted for the conditions of two 
fields in Western Siberia - its shape and nature are specific. Similarly, you can adapt the graph 
to any other field and get the correct results. 
The analysis was carried out by the authors of the article on 6 wells, where hydraulic 
fracturing using FiberFrac technology was used. The data are shown in table 1.

improving the hydraulic fracturing operation, described the essence and results of applying 
the FiberFrac technology, the success of which was 83%, and the level of profitable 
production was 305.58 tons.

Research of the mathematical model of technological calculation of cryogenic outriggers for 
LNG filling 
Vanchugov Ivan Mikhailovich, Zharkova Vladislava Vladimirovna 
Student 
Gubkin University 
 
ABSTRACT 
The paper investigates a mathematical model of the operational calculation of 
cryogenic outriggers for LNG filling. typical designs of remote filling facilities (VSN) of 
liquefied natural gas (LNG) are considered. The disadvantages and advantages of the VSN are 
analyzed in detail, a comparative analysis with stationary berths and VSN for oil and 
petroleum products is given. 
 
KEYWORDS 
LNG, modeling, technological process, outrigger berthing facilities, cryogenic 
installations. 
 
The liquefied natural gas (LNG) industry is divided into large-tonnage production, the 
main purpose of which is to supply natural gas to world markets in liquefied form [1], and 
low-tonnage production aimed at interregional trade and meeting demand in the domestic 
market as fuel for remote areas or alternative motor fuel [2]. 
In Russia, the first large-capacity LNG plant was commissioned in the south of 
Sakhalin Island in February 2009. The plant has a design capacity of 9.6 million tons on the 
resource base of the Lunskoye field. The next implemented project was the Yamal LNG plant 
based on the Yuzhno-Tambeyskoye field. The medium-tonnage implemented projects were 
the Vysotsk LNG project, the Portovaya CS LNG Complex [3]. 
The infrastructure for the shipment of LNG for export from the above-mentioned 
plants is carried out through the construction of a shipping complex located at a distance from 
the shore and connected to the coastal structures by transitional bridges or overpasses. 
The shipping complex has proven itself as a safe and reliable solution for LNG 
shipments. However, the length of the overpasses can vary from tens to hundreds of meters. 
The construction of such a stationary complex is due to a number of requirements for the 
terrain and difficulties in the implementation of the project, greatly increasing investment. An 
alternative solution for LNG shipment is the use of an outrigger berthing facility. 
The main essence of the mathematical model of LNG filling outriggers is that this 
model consists of several parts that allow the calculation of a thermohydraulic mathematical 
model and describe the calculation of hydraulics and the operation of outriggers. 
The simulation results showed the possibility of using cryogenic outrigger structures 
for LNG filling, as well as the selection of a number of conditions necessary for the operation 
of these structures. 
 
REFERENCES: 
1. Karpov A.B., Kondratenko A.D., Meshcherin I.V., Rossijskie proizvodstva po szhizheniyu

Prospects for the development of gas hydrate deposits 
Vatuzov Sergey Maksimovich, Gutnikova Yulia Mikhailovna 
Student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas 
(National Research University) 
 
ABSTRACT 
The research considers the properties of gas hydrates and their structure as well as methods of 
using hydrates as alternative sources of energy. What is more, the information on the gas hydrate 
location is analysed as well as methods of their detection. Finally, the research considers gas hydrate 
field development based on the world’s first offshore field. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Gas hydrate deposits, gas hydrates, development, field, wells, shelf. 
 
Gas hydrates are an ice mass with a hydrocarbon gas enclosed in it, most often methane, or it 
is a mixture of water and methane in certain concentrations, capable of forming ice under certain 
thermobaric conditions. Gas hydrates belong to the metastable structures.  
Gas hydrates are stable if there is a low temperature in the permafrost on land or low 
temperature and high pressure of the sedimentary column of the deep ocean. The zone of gas hydrates 
stability is known to be established. In the open ocean the zone starts from a water depth of 450 
meters, and under the ocean floor it stands to the level of (geothermal) gradient of sedimentary rocks. 
As an alternative source of natural gas, gas hydrates, despite their large volume in the ocean, are 
considered in a remote perspective. Commonly, the presence of gas hydrates in the ocean is in a 
dispersed state or in small concentrations. 
The development of gas hydrate deposits is a promising area for research because of their 
huge reserves and environmental friendliness, but commercial production of such hydrocarbons takes 
place only in China and Japan. For example, in 2017 in the South China Sea, Chinese oil workers 
managed to start extracting natural gas from ice sediments and transport it to the surface. Japan has 
also been conducting research in this area for quite a long time, and in 2013 the depressurization 
method was applied to develop the Nankai gas-hydrate field. 
This paper presents an analysis of the development of the world's first offshore Nankai 
methane hydrate field on the east coast of Japan by JOGMEC. To develop the Nankai offshore gas 
hydrate field, a highly concentrated hydrate field discovered in turbidite sediments near the East 
Nankai Trough, seismic surveys and exploration drilling were performed. 
In conducting the world's first offshore pilot production of methane from hydrates in the field 
below the seafloor, the main objectives were: 
1) to determine the flow rate in a short period of time (one to several weeks),  
2) to achieve stability, integrity of wells drilled in loose sediments,  
3) introduce a monitoring technology to collect information on the state of methane hydrate in 
the development. 
The paper shows the problems encountered in the development of this field, as well as ways to 
solve them and the analysis of the reasons for commercial production of gas hydrates in Nankai not 
being started. 
 
REFERENCES: 
1. Malukov V.P., Tokarev I.S., Research on the development of the nankai gas hydrates field. RUDN

2. Myslivets A.A., Dubodel A.K., Development of gas hydrates. Electronic scientific journal

Current state and methods of combating environmental crimes 
Vermensky Nikita Sergeevich 
Supervisor: Shelyago N.D. 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas (National Research University) 
 
ABSTRACT 
This article examines the issues related to the commission of environmental violations, 
the specifics of their commission. Possible measures are proposed to reduce their number, as 
well as to prevent harm to legally protected values. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Environmental offenses, responsibility, environmental protection, hydrocarbons, crime 
prevention. 
 
Today's world realities allow us to live in a world where there are still enough 
resources for a full-fledged being. Oil, gas and coal will continue to supply people for a long 
time. Nevertheless, usage of hydrocarbons leads to negative consequences. Every year, from 
19 to 20 million tons of oil are spilled in the Russian Federation. As the scientists warn, it is 
easy to contaminate nature, but it will take decades to restore. 
Issues related to the environment are pressing especially in the regions of production 
of hydrocarbons. Meanwhile, each step of the oil business is making its own unfavorable 
contribution (Upstream, Midstream, Downstream). Both incompetence and unprofessionalism 
of employees in this sphere, and the serious wear of equipment, contribute to the situations 
which lead to accidents and spills. 
Due to the fact that offenses against nature are among the most dangerous, as they 
influence the people's lives, the legislatures drew attention to them and identified elements of 
environmental crimes in a separate chapter of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation. 
Environmental protection should be one of the highest priorities of each country. It is almost 
impossible to exclude the impact on the environment as a consequence of human activity, and 
the effects of such activity are often irrecoverable. Every year, the oil and gas industry 
pollutes up to 15 thousand hectares of land, emits about 2.5 million tons of air pollutants into 
the atmosphere. Losses of oil and petroleum products in the Russian Federation amount to 
more than 20 million tons. With an oil price of $60 per barrel, the damage to the Russian 
economy is more than $7 billion.  
However, punishment for an environmental crime committed will not purify polluted 
air and will not save fauna, poisoned by oil. It is much more effective to create measures 
aimed at preventing offenses. These measures may include the formation of the right legal 
awareness to protect the environment. In addition, the state can allocate additional funds to 
upgrade the equipment. The next step may be to take measures against persons who are 
involved in environmental offenses. Also, these persons must constantly report on the 
condition at the fuel and energy facilities. 
Thus, we analyzed the above provisions and came to the conclusion that the Russian 
Federation should take into account digitalization and take advantage of its advantages. It is 
also necessary to improve legislation in the field of environmental offenses, using the 
experience of other countries. For example, the criminal prosecution of the drilling contractor 
Transocean by the Brazilian authorities. At the same time, we should not forget about the 
moral motivation of citizens not to pollute the environment. 
Currently, according to various sources, equipment wear is about 60-70%, so it is 
urgent to take measures to eliminate outdated units. If the technical component is not 

441 
 
changed, accidents will become more frequent, which will lead to an increase in 
environmental disasters. 
In conclusion, it’s important to emphasize possible measures to prevent environmental 
offenses (subsidies for updating equipment, revoking licenses of companies with old material 
and technical base, encouraging reports of violations of environmental legislation, raising the 
legal (environmental) awareness of citizens (including mass media campaigns raising the 
issue of the Earth not being restored as fast as it is polluted). 
 
REFERENCES:

3. Korotun V.Y., Actual problems of environmental crimes / V. Y. Korotun. - Text: direct //

Analysis of methods of utilization of APG on the Norwegian and Russian offshore 
Volkov Alexandr Vladimirovich1, Andreas Løkås Halvorsen2 
1,2Master’s student 
1Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas,  
2University of Stavanger 
Academic supervisor: D.G-M.Sc., professor Dziublo A.D. 
 
ABSTRACT 
This article discusses the main methods of utilization of associated petroleum gas on 
the Norwegian and Russian fields. It is shown that at the moment the problems of APG 
utilization are becoming more and more popular for Russian and Norwegian companies due 
to restrictions aimed at reducing the flaring and release of associated petroleum gas. Examples 
of its rational use are given. The main factors that influence decision-making by Russian and 
Norwegian companies regarding the use or flaring and release of associated petroleum gas are 
shown. The article compares the main technologies for the utilization and further use of APG 
in Russia and Norway. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Associated petroleum gas, offshore field development, GGFR, flaring, flared gas, 
environmental protection 
 
The issue of choosing a technology for the utilization of associated petroleum gas has 
become particularly relevant in recent times. The reduction in requirements for APG 
emissions into the environment leads to an increase in fines for the simplest method of APG 
utilization - flaring, which leads to an increase in demand among companies for technologies 
aimed at eco-economic utilization of associated petroleum gas. 
In world practice, a lot of experience has been accumulated in the rational use of APG, 
various technologies for its utilization have been developed and tested. In particular, 
Norwegian companies have managed to achieve great success in the collection and processing 
of APG. Also in Russia, active work is underway to create technologies to reduce APG 
utilization. 
Norway's offshore oil fields located on the Norwegian Continental Shelf represent one 
of the best examples of the implementation of an oil production policy that meets stringent 
environmental requirements. One of the main uses of APG in Norway is injection into 
reservoirs. APG from wells with high GOR is redistributed to fields with low GOR. In 
Russia, work is also being actively carried out to create and improve technologies, as well as 
equipment for the utilization and processing of APG. A state strategy has been created to 
ensure a 95% level of APG utilization. The article discusses and compares various 
technologies used in Russia and Norway.

Participation of Russian companies in the development of hydrogen energy. 
Guzenko Sofya Valeryevna 
Student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas 
Scientific Supervisor: Associate Professor Popadko N.V. 
 
ABSTRACT 
The paper considers the goals and measures for the implementation of the «Energy 
Strategy of the Russian Federation until 2035». The results already achieved are briefly 
reviewed. P planned and already existing projects of leading Russian companies in the 
development of hydrogen energy were analyzed. Foreign hydrogen strategies are briefly 
mentioned. Attention is also paid to Russia's cooperation with foreign countries. The 
competitive advantages of Russia in the development of hydrogen energy in comparison with 
potential market participating countries are revealed. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Hydrogen energy, hydrogen production and consumption, roadmap, production 
technologies, energy strategy. 
 
Hydrogen energy is rapidly gaining popularity against the background of modern 
trends. The main drivers of universal hydrogen interest are:  
• the need to ensure carbon neutrality;  
• reduced demand for traditional energy resources;  
• increasing the share of renewable energy sources; 
• active development of transport infrastructure; 
• technology development; 
The most competitive and promising area of development of Russian hydrogen energy 
is the introduction of the following 3 types of hydrogen: 1) the development of «gray» 
hydrogen; 2) the development of «yellow» hydrogen; 3) the development of «blue (blue)» 
hydrogen. To date, the production of «green» hydrogen in Russia is not considered as 
promising due to the poorly developed renewable energy sector. 
The development of hydrogen energy begins with the study of domestic market and its 
needs. In the interests of overall energy security, we must first determine our own hydrogen 
needs in order to ensure reliable supplies to foreign markets in the future. Russian oil and gas 
companies should prepare for the production of hydrogen from renewable sources in the 
immediate vicinity of sales markets - primarily in the EU countries. 
Russia's energy strategy for the period up to 2035 provides for the development of 
hydrogen production and consumption in the country, the entry of domestic companies among 
the world leaders in terms of its exports. 
All major oil and gas producing companies see prospects in this direction. These 
include: Rusatom Overseas (part of the Rosatom State Corporation), Gazprom Neft. 
Moreover, in the long term, Gazprom and Rosatom may become competitors in the hydrogen 
market, says Alexey Zhikharev, partner in the electric power industry at Vygon Consulting. 
Rosatom is already positioning itself as a future major manufacturer: the company has agreed 
on a joint export-oriented project with Japan, and is discussing with Hyundai the construction 
of infrastructure for hydrogen cars. 
Only two corporations are listed in the roadmap, but NOVATEK is also interested in 
the hydrogen business. The company is actively studying the production of so-called blue 
hydrogen: also from gas, but with the release and subsequent disposal of CO2. 

445 
 
LUKOIL also plans to implement a modest project for the production of green 
hydrogen in the Krasnodar Territory with a volume of 13 tons/year. 
Russian companies are already producing hydrogen, but mainly for industry. This is 
the cheapest and most common in the world so-called gray hydrogen from gas, its production 
is accompanied by CO2 emissions.  But the production of hydrogen, to which the roadmap for 
the development of hydrogen energy is dedicated, will be clean. Gazprom aims to produce 
blue hydrogen. 
Rosatom plans to complete the construction of a landfill in 2024 to study the 
possibility of using hydrogen fuel in railway transport. With such decarbonized technology, 
Russian companies will be able to increase the production of domestic hydrogen fuel, as well 
as modernize its use technologies over time. All this will allow Russia in the long term to take 
a leading position in the export of hydrogen on the global market, and the AETS project and 
its implementation abroad can make Russia the undisputed leader in the export of nuclear 
power plants for hydrogen production, since only a country with a full technological cycle of 
atomic hydrogen energy can implement this project on the world market. 
It is planned that Russia will export about 200 thousand tons of hydrogen in 2024, and 
by 2025 10 times more - about 2 million tons.

Calculation of well grid density parameter for different types of well completion in oil fields 
Denisov Vladislav Igorevich 1, Astapova Daria Anatolyevna 2 
1 Junior Researcher, 2 Project Manager 
1 National Research Tomsk Polytechnic University, Tomsk, Russia 
1.2 AO "TomskNIPIneft", Tomsk, Russia 
 
ABSTRACT 
The density of the well grid (WDG) in the oilfield business is a very important 
parameter, the definition of which allows drawing conclusions regarding the sweep 
efficiency, oil recovery and the development system as a whole. However, the initial 
definition of WDG as the area of the reservoir per one vertical well is currently complicated 
by the use of various completion methods. Thus, one of the important points is the reasonable 
consideration of the presence in the planned or existing grid of wells with a horizontal (HS), 
horizontal sidetrack (SHS), hydraulic fracturing (HF) and multi-stage hydraulic fracturing 
(MSHF). At present, the existing approaches to assessing the density of a well pattern differ 
significantly. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Well grid density (WDG), oil recovery factor (ORF), sweep efficiency, horizontal 
wells, hydraulic fracturing. 
 
The object of study of this work is the density of the well grid (WDG). WDG is one of 
the parameters that characterizes the area of the production facility, which falls on one well. 
This parameter is decisive when choosing the optimal development system for the reservoir. 
The value of WDG is given in the protocols of the Central Commission for Development 
(CCD), is used in the operational calculation of reserves (OPZ) when justifying the boundary 
of categories of reserves, is used when calculating the oil recovery factor (ORF) by statistical 
methods, and is also used in justifying economic efficiency (determining the point " 
inflection" by NPV), which is extremely important for the selection of the optimal 
development system. 
In the course of the work, we collected data on several fields at the 3-4 stages of 
development, drilled, with a formed system (layers - Upper Jurassic). The collected data were 
analyzed and the following conclusions were made on their basis: 
1. At the moment, there is no single method for accurately determining the WDG, 
which became the goal of the work; 
2. Initially, the task was set to determine the methodology for calculating the WDG 
for wells with HW and hydraulic fracturing. In this regard, on the basis of an analytical 
review, the formulas for calculating the WDG for the LP with hydraulic fracturing and HW 
with hydraulic fracturing were refined; 
3. With the help of these formulas, coefficients were calculated that take into 
account the effect of hydraulic fracturing for NPS and HW. Thus, tools were obtained to more 
accurately calculate the WDG, but they needed to be confirmed; 
4. First, the refined formula for the HS was analyzed, which basically uses the 
formula of S.F. Mulyavina. Next, coefficients were analyzed that take into account the effect 
of hydraulic fracturing. In the course of the work, it was confirmed that these parameters 
provide a greater correlation between the WDG and surface efficiency; 
As the practice of developing most reservoirs shows, with an increase in the 
development rate (fracturing, compaction), at a certain stage, the final oil recovery factor 
decreases, so one of the areas of work is also the analysis of the relationship of the studied 
parameters with a cost-effective oil recovery factor. 

447

Supervised machine learning for bottomhole pressure prediction 
Dormenev Vladislav Sergeevich 
Student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas 
(National Research University) 
Scientific Supervisor: Associate Professor Khabibullin R.A. 
 
ABSTRACT 
Under current oil and gas production conditions characterized by mature fields, data 
accuracy becomes the most critical challenge. The aim of the paper is to provide a clear guide 
for selecting an appropriate forecasting algorithm in accordance with the requirements of the 
task. In this paper, different machine learning techniques were applied for the bottomhole 
pressure prediction. The best algorithm for estimating pressure at well bore in the absence of 
gauge data was selected and tested on a larger quantity of data. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Bottomhole pressure, machine learning techniques, artificial intelligence, empirical 
correlation. 
 
Machine learning is a discipline that focuses on the development and application of 
data-based learning of computational models to deal with some concrete problems [1]. 
Artificial intelligence and machine learning methods have been increasingly used in recent 
years. This growth in usage has been driven by the enormous amount of data held by 
technology giants such as Facebook, Netflix, and others. 
The application of machine learning techniques in the oil and gas industry to a wide 
range of production tasks is a key trend in data monetization. There are many articles and case 
studies published on the implementation of machine learning and related techniques in the 
petroleum industry. However, there are still not many widely used practical methods, as has 
happened with empirical correlations. 
Forecasts are the foundation for decisions on field management [2]. This work aims to 
create a model based on the obtained data, using machine learning algorithms, that can 
accurately predict pressure at well bore. Bottomhole pressure is essential knowledge for 
petroleum engineers. Its accurate determination makes well tests and reservoir diagnostics 
more effective. The model discussed in this paper may enable engineers to avoid installing 
downhole gauges, thus reducing overall well cost. 
Data gathered from different wells in the same field were used for that purpose. The 
model was trained on more than 10000 observed results. One output parameter and more than 
10 input parameters were selected. All these data were divided into a training sample and a 
test sample. By comparing different metrics, the best machine learning method was selected, 
which is planned to be tested on other oil fields.

The use of neural networks in spectral core analysis 
Efimenko Anastasia Eduardovna 
Bachelor student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gaz 
(National Research University)  
Academic advisor: Lecturer Sharapova E.V. 
 
ABSTRACT 
The point of this work was to develop software based on a self-learning neural 
network, whose work is aimed at studying the chemical composition of the core salvage, by 
analyzing the spectrum of rocks obtained using spectrographs, which, in turn, irradiating 
sludge (particles of drilled rock) and reservoir fluids released from the drilling mud of the 
studied sample, provide spectrum of chemical elements in the irradiated rock. The probability 
of the presence of oil in the reservoir is calculated, by analyzing the spectrum. In addition, it 
is possible to use any programming languages for neural network design. The MongoDB 
database was used to store the current progress of neural network training process. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Neural network, spectrum analyses, spectrographs, liner spectrum, prediction of 
geological horizons, analysis of core salvage. 
 
In the process of drilling wells, especially in cases of complex geological structure of 
the section, maximum information is required about the material composition, reservoir 
properties and oil and gas saturation of the rocks passed by the well. These properties, in 
particular, are determined by the results of the analysis of core salvage and slurry material. [1] 
There are many different ways to determine the chemical composition of rocks, among 
them the most famous are thermography (registration of temperature changes when minerals 
are heated), chemical analysis (for example, by using reagents), assay and atomic absorption 
analyses, technical tests and others. But the most common method is spectral analysis. 
Emission spectral analysis is commonly understood as methods for determining the 
chemical composition of a substance by the spectrum emitted by its atoms.[2] Different 
chemical elements, under the influence of external forces (for example, temperature) in a 
gaseous state, are excited and emit light radiation, which are decomposed into a spectrum by 
special devices - sprectographs, and then photographed. [3] 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
However, in order to identify rocks by their spectral analysis, it is often necessary to 
attract highly qualified personnel (for the analysis of spectrograms). At the same time, it is 
necessary to take into account all the advantages and disadvantages of the human factor. 
Among the disadvantages are the inattention of a person, significant financial costs, the need 
for continuous professional development of employees, etc. At the same time, the risk of error 
is quite high and can lead to the destruction of the studied sample or an incorrect prediction of 
the presence or absence of oil-saturated layers of the geological horizon. 

450 
 
The purpose of this work was to minimize such errors by designing an artificial 
intelligence system aimed at recognizing the chemical composition of a particular rock 
sample. A trained single-layer perceptron recognizes a linear spectrum of individual chemical 
elements. Based on the decision of the neural network, an assumption is made about the 
presence or absence of oil in the reservoir. 
The integration of neural networks for chemical composition recognition has a number 
of advantages. Firstly, the neural network is resistant to noise, therefore, even a low-quality 
sample can be correctly studied and determined. Secondly, even with significant damage to 
their components, neural networks will be able to produce correct results. Thirdly, if the 
previously unexplored rock is obtained during the study, then over time the neural network 
will be able to recognize it and quickly determine the oil and gas potential of the reservoir in 
the future. 
 
REFERENCES: 
1. A.S. Moiseenko, i.v. Egorova Infraredspectral information and measuring systems of 
research of rocks. Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gaz. 
2.Bocker Y.U. Spectroscopy. – m.: Technosfera, 2009. – 528 p. 3. 
3. Handbook of lithology/edited by N. B. Wassoevicha, V. L. Librovicha, N. V. Logvinenko, 
V. I. Marchen co. - m.: Nedra, 1983. 509 p.

 Evaluation of the study of the oil industry in the field of ecology of the Potochnoye field 
Закиров Азат Ильмирович, Силантьев Иван Евгеньевич 
Студент 
ГБОУ ВО Альметьевский государственный нефтяной институт 
Научный руководитель: доцент, к.п.н. Хусаинова Р.Р. 
 
ABSTRACT 
For a long time, the oil and gas industry has played an important role in human life. 
Every year, the pace of development of the oil and gas sector is increasing (hard-to-recover 
oil reserves are brought into development, new wells are drilled, new technologies are being 
industrially tested). With the growth of the oil industry, the negative impact of this sector on 
the environment is increasing. Harmful emissions and waste from production activities are 
generated at all stages of field development. This article assesses the impact of the oil and gas 
sector on the environment associated with drilling wells, arrangement of clusters and routes to 
wells, formed during the development of the Potochnoye field. This article discusses in detail 
the volume of emissions during field work and measures to reduce them. 
 
 
KEYWORDS  
Environment, emissions, field development, well drilling. 
 
The modern field development system is standardized and practically unchanged over 
the past years. The development of hydrocarbon deposits is of a permissive nature, in 
particular, it requires prior permission for activities from the relevant state bodies and is 
regulated by a package of existing regulatory documents, methodological and legislative 
documents. Possible emissions (pollution) into the atmosphere during the impact on the 
environment are substantiated. 
Environmental impact assessment (EIA) is a mandatory part of project documentation. 
EIA is carried out after assessing the current state of the environment, taking into account the 
action plan for environmental protection. This Document contains information on emissions 
and other negative environmental impacts. 
All calculations of quantitative indicators in assessing the impact of facilities on the 
environment were made and carried out on the basis of consolidated standards calculated for 
similar projects. 
Sources of pollutant emissions during construction and installation works are: boiler 
house; diesel power station; emissions from car engines and construction equipment; molar 
work; pouring works; drilling fluid mixing system. 
In the operating mode of facility management, the main sources of emissions of 
harmful substances into the atmosphere during oil production are as follows: flanges in 
fittings are loosely connected; sealants for moving joints of pumping equipment; container 
breathers; air ducts of the chemical reagents input block [1]. 
During the operation of the designed facilities, the following aspects were calculated: 
emissions into the atmosphere from process units installed at the facilities; air emissions from 
mobile vehicles in accordance with the emission standards of each pollutant; production waste 
in compliance with the norm of industrial waste generation; oily waste; volumes of produced 
water in terms of field development indicators. 
The mass of harmful substances emitted from stationary and mobile sources during 
well drilling is calculated and is not presented in this thesis. 
During the period of well drilling and construction of facilities, the average annual 
emissions of pollutants into the atmosphere from stationary sources will be 141.29 tons/year 
and from road and construction equipment and motor vehicles - 200.8 tons/year. 

452 
 
In the operating mode of operation of the designed facilities, pollutants from stationary 
sources in the amount of 13730.9 tons/year will be emitted into the atmosphere annually, 
emissions from vehicles will amount to 47.1 tons/year. 
To prevent air pollution at the enterprise, it is necessary to take the following measures 
to reduce the harmful effects: complete sealing of equipment; selection of equipment taking 
into account the explosion, fire hazard and toxicity of products; Fuel and lubricants must be 
delivered and stored in closed containers, it is necessary to keep records of spent and used 
fuels and lubricants; optimize the process of fuel combustion in boiler houses and heaters 
according to regime maps; 
The use of associated and natural petroleum gas should be reflected in the projects for 
the field [2]. The level of use of associated produced gas during the operation of the field 
should be at least 97.5%.

Greenhouse gas emissions management on the oil pipeline transport 
Zvorykina Anastasia 
Research associate 
Transneft R&D, LLC 
Scientific research supervisor: Gaisin M.T. 
 
ABSTRACT  
The international climate agenda, as well as the new trends in Russian legislation 
oblige industries to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from production processes. The main oil 
transport has a low level of emissions compared to the downstream and upstream sectors, but 
still emissions do not allow achieving the goals set in the 2015 Paris Agreement. The paper 
describes the main features of greenhouse gas emissions management at oil pipelines, as well 
as substantiates the main measures to reduce emissions. 
 
KEYWORDS  
Greenhouse gas, pipeline, climate change, energy transition, carbon management  
 
7 million people suffer from climate change caused diseases annually. Climate 
changes cause natural disasters such as inundations, forest fires etc., industrial accidents, as 
well as aggravation of social and gender inequality. Climate change resilience and adaptation 
stay among the main topics of international discussions and require the active involvement of 
all participants in the world community. 
Russia adopted many regulations related to the greenhouse gas emissions during 2020 
and 2021. Among them is the Strategy of the Russian Federation for Low Carbon Dioxide 
Emissions. The Strategy includes the low carbon scenario which assumes achieving the 
carbon neutrality by 2060. This actions on the part of the state show us the relevance of the 
topic at the sectoral, national and international level.  
Climate changes may have a negative impact on the oil pipeline industry. thawing of 
permafrost layers causes damage to infrastructure, increased precipitation, increased risk of 
forest fires. Moreover, there are the transition period risks that come along with the legislation 
and market changes. For instance, the industry could suffer from the introduction of carbon 
quotas, and a decline in the oil consumption market. 
Due to the relevance of the climate agenda, Transneft, PJC is studying the way of the 
climate impact reduction of the oil pipeline transport. The greenhouse gas emissions are 
calculated using Russian methodological recommendations and international ones from the 
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) and Greenhouse gas protocol 
standard. Fuel consumption data were collected for the entire group of companies and 
obtained by calculation method. 
Based on our research the midstream sector has the lowest climate impact compared to 
the downstream and upstream sectors. The main source of the Scope 1 emissions is the 
hydrocarbon fuel combustion in the boiler equipment and the transport emissions. We also 
used the methodical recommendations to calculate the Scope 2 emissions caused by the use of 
the electricity.  

454 
 
  
Figure 1 Greenhouse gas emissions in Russian oil industry 
 
Despite relatively small emissions produced by the oil pipeline transport, achieving 
carbon neutrality in the company requires some measures to reduce emissions and to enhance 
sequestration. Among these measures we can distinguish, several directions: first of all, a 
reduction of the Scope 1 emissions through the use of energy-saving measures and the 
replacement of the boiler fuel with the low-carbon one (such as natural gas), as well as saving 
the motor fuel and replacing transport with a more environmentally friendly one. Measures to 
reduce emissions will not allow achieving neutrality without a dramatic decrease in 
production volumes, therefore, measures carbon dioxide sequestration are envisaged. 
Transneft, PJC is currently working on an emissions management strategy.

Study of borehole stability problems by geomechanical modeling 
Zeytunyan Artur Ashotovich 
Bachelor Student  
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas 
(National Research University) 
Scientific Supervisor: Cand. of Technical Sciences, Arkhipov A.I. 
Academic adviser: Cand. of Sc., Assoc. Prof. Amitirova-Turgeneva D.L. 
 
ABSTRACT  
The paper studies geomechanical models that make it possible to predict the risks 
associated with the stability of the wellbore, the oil gas water inflow, and the collapse of the 
well walls. It is possible to prevent emergencies when the conditions of  rocks destruction are 
known. With the help of software products, graphs of the distribution of various stresses in 
the wellbore are presented using the Kirsch equation. According to the results of the study, it 
became possible to set the trajectory of the well and describe the stress state of the wellbore. 
 
KEYWORDS  
Geomechanics, geomechanical modeling, wellbore stability, mechanical properties of 
rocks, geophysical study of the well, collapse, python. 
 
Geomechanical modeling of the borehole zone of the well allows reducing the 
nonproductive time of well construction, the risks of kicks, collapse and lost circulation of 
drilling mud. The most common and effective method of geomechanical exploration of wells 
is the selection and study of the core which is time-consuming and costly, therefore indirect 
methods are used to study the mechanical properties of rocks, such as mini-hydraulic 
fracturing, acoustic and microimage azimuthal electrical logging. 
The aim of the study is to determine the optimal direction of drilling horizontal wells. 
To achieve this aim the following tasks were set: 
1) to identify the main patterns of rocks behavior in the formation of the well bottom; 
2) to analyze known solutions to the problem of the borehole walls stability, taking into 
account the geomechanical situation in the well; 
3) to build a graphical representation of principal stresses in the borehole zone. 
Analytical and numerical methods of analyzing the mechanical rocks behavior in the 
case of elastic deformation were used to solve the tasks. 
An interactive software product has been developed to illustrate the distribution of 
principal stresses in the borehole in polar coordinates at various deviation and azimuth angles 
for a real well (fig. 1). The values shown in the picture can be used to evaluate the rock 
strength according to the main failure criteria used in modeling. 

456 
 
  
Figure 1. Distribution of three principal stresses in the wellbore, where  
Profile - test profile for algorithm performance evaluation, red dot indicates the path of 
interest; 
Sigma_1, Sigma_2, Sigma_3 – maximum, intermediate and minimum stress distribution 
respectively 
 
To sum up, the proposed software optimizes the borehole trajectory by minimizing the 
breakout gradient value with the condition of constant leak-off gradient. It should be 
mentioned that another major effects of such optimization is the mud weight window 
extension, which can effectively solve the environmental issues and significantly improve the 
profitability of production. 
 
REFERENCES: 
1. Fundamentals of Drilling Engineering Kindle Edition by Robert F. Mitchell, Stefan F. 
Miska, 2011 – 710 pages. 
2. Garavand A. Geomechanical modeling of the state of the near-barrel zone of an 
unconsolidated highly porous reservoir during well drilling: abstract of the PhD thesis: 2019.

Digital Oil Image by the Method of Thin Layer Chromatography in Different Eluents 
Issabek Zhanel1, Mishin Viktor Dmitrievich2 
1Student, 2PhD Student 
1,2Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas 
(National Research University) 
Scientific Supervisor: DScTech, Professor Safiyeva R.Z. 
 
ABSTRACT 
The main purpose of the study was to get a digital image of various oils and to further 
provide information of their components. The basic principles of choosing a thin-layer 
chromatographic (TLC) method, as well as the principle of obtaining an oil footprint, are 
described. A method for the distribution of oil high-molecular components (HMC) into 
inactive and interfacial components in various eluents was developed. The technique is based 
on the study of the composition of oil using digital processing of the obtained chromatograms, 
which provides for the use of digital parameters of oil traces. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Oil, oil footprint, thin layer chromatography, separation. 
 
Oils are unique natural objects considered within the framework of the colloidal-
chemical approach as petroleum dispersed systems (PDS), characterized by fine differences in 
the molecular weight distribution of high molecular weight compounds (HMC) - asphaltenes. 
The main difficulty of analysts in the study of such systems is the appropriate sample 
preparation of the research object, taking into account its colloidal-chemical nature. The role 
of the uncertain factor in relation to PDS is significantly higher, since the solubility of 
asphaltenes in a hydrocarbon dispersion medium should be taken into account. It strongly 
influences the results of the analysis of the composition and properties of such objects due to 
the tendency of asphaltenes to intermolecular interactions (IIM), aggregation in the bulk 
phase and/or adsorption at the presence of a developed solid surface. On the one hand, this 
circumstance complicates the analysis, and on the other hand, it opens up new possibilities for 
characterizing asphaltene-containing systems, which is the purpose of our studies.  
The TLC method was chosen as an accessible uncomplicated technique, which made it 
possible to determine the distribution parameters of the HMC of heavy oil (using the example 
of oil from the Yarega field) in the studied polar and non-polar eluents in a thin layer on a 
solid polar surface of silica gel. The distribution coefficients of the HMC of oil were 
determined visually, by UV spectroscopy (285 nm) and using the Nastyukov formolite 
reaction (a mixture of conc. 98% sulfuric acid and 2% formalin). The resulting images were 
processed according to a specific digital algorithm, which included preparing chromatograms 
in the Paint editor, converting them to a gray scale, converting them to a matrix and 
constructing the corresponding spectra (the distance from the start line is plotted along the 
horizontal axis, and intensity along the vertical axis). Each experiment was carried out at least 
7 times. The root-mean-square error of measurements, carried out on the basis of measuring 
the coordinates of the oil peak, was 1% along the X-axis and 8% along the Y-axis. 
Thus, a methodological approach has been developed to create a digital image of the 
distribution of the HMC of oil, which is characterized by good reproducibility of the results of 
TLC measurements. The practical value of the developed method is shown.

Legal support of cryptocurrency in fuel and energy complex 
Kipina Lada Alexandrovna 
Student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas (National Research University) 
Supervisor: Shelyago N.D. 
 
ABSTRACT 
This research is devoted to the consideration of the legislation on cryptocurrency in 
the Russian Federation. The work considers how the fuel and energy complex is involved in 
obtaining and using cryptocurrencies. The purpose of the work is to study and analyze the 
legal provisions on cryptocurrency and, based on the results of the study, analyze the legality 
and possibility of involving fuel and energy enterprises in the field of cryptocurrencies. 
 
KEYWORDS  
Fuel and energy complex, cryptocurrency, means of payment, fuel and energy 
enterprises, mining. 
 
With the advent of digital technologies, the life of not only each individual, but also 
enterprises, the state and other large objects have changed significantly. The advent of 
technology contributed to the emergence of new means of communication, education, led to a 
change in the methods and time of enterprise management, moreover, payment methods were 
changed, and, accordingly, the forms of money and money circulation. More recently, a type 
of virtual money has been created, which in many countries are equivalent to real ones-
cryptocurrency. The creation of a special type of currency has become a great innovation in 
the economic life of society, which may soon lead to a complete change in the forms of 
monetary circulation. Nevertheless, in the Russian Federation, the cryptocurrency still does 
not have a stable position and monetary weight, although many countries are ready to 
cooperate, especially in the field of fuel and energy, with the help of cryptocurrencies. 
The relevance of this work lies in the fact that cryptocurrency is a rapidly developing 
phenomenon that is spreading more and more every day, and is becoming part of the 
international market. In addition to the exchange method of mastering this currency, there is a 
method of mining, which is currently being tried to be implemented through enterprises of the 
fuel and energy complex. 
The issue of the legalization of cryptocurrencies is acute in the Russian Federation. So, 
on January 1, 2021, the federal law "On Digital Financial Assets" entered into force, which 
recognized cryptocurrency as a legal monetary unit. Nevertheless, article 14 of this law 
establishes that cryptocurrency cannot be a means of payment for goods, works, services, 
since the ruble is the official currency in the country. This rule also applies to the products of 
fuel and energy enterprises, although many countries are ready to cooperate with the 
possibility of paying for goods with cryptocurrency, recognizing it as an official means of 
payment. In addition, the President of the Russian Federation Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin 
claims that the products of the fuel and energy complex are not the objects that should be paid 
for in this way, since the cryptocurrency is sufficiently unstable and unstable. This, in turn, 
may affect the national economy of the country in the event of a sharp change in the value 
rate, which is currently quite vulnerable. 
It is important to note that fuel and energy enterprises have become an object through 
which they realize the possibility of mining cryptocurrencies in the fields. The use of 
associated petroleum gas, which is a by-product of production, is another source of electricity 
generation, which allows to engage in a fairly profitable business, since it is pumped into gas 
turbine and gas piston installations that are capable of generating free energy, which makes it 

460 
 
useful to dispose of excess gas through mining. This activity allows enterprises not only to 
accumulate cryptocurrency themselves by investing in the future, but also to attract investors 
who are ready to place mining capacities at their enterprises. For example, Gazprom installed 
a mobile container designed for mining and connected it to electricity from associated 
petroleum gas, which allowed the use of raw materials in an area with unprofitable 
transportation. Since the Decree of the Government of the Russian Federation of January 8, 
2009 established that the amount of burned associated gas should reach no more than five 
percent of the extracted associated gas, this method of using this gas allows it to be used 
rationally. Nevertheless, mining and cryptocurrencies in general are still not fully detailed in 
the law «On Digital Financial Assets», which leads this activity into a gray zone, that is, 
devoid of legal regulation. 
Analyzing the above provisions, it can be assumed that Russian legislation is already 
close to the legal regulation of mining as a method of obtaining cryptocurrencies. It is 
important at the legislative level to consolidate the ability of fuel and energy companies to 
attract investors who will benefit both for themselves and for the development of the 
enterprises themselves. In addition, it is necessary to grant the right to companies to use 
deposits and their enterprises for the purpose of mining. It is also impossible to ignore the 
quantitative limits of the usage of associated petroleum gas, increasing the existing rate of 5 
percent. This, in turn, will allow us to develop a system of more environmentally friendly 
disposal of unnecessary gas during production, as well as the proceeds will be used to develop 
the latest technologies for the fuel and energy complex and the flourishing of the country's 
economy as a whole. Speaking about the use of cryptocurrencies as a means of payment, it is 
important to emphasize that until the crypto market becomes more stable and more 
independent of political and information processes, it is quite risky for enterprises and the 
economy of the state to make transactions with petroleum and gas products, since the fuel and 
energy complex is an important component of the budget of Russia. 
In conclusion, it is important to emphasize that the creation and use of 
cryptocurrencies in the fuel and energy complex has all the possibilities for prosperity, since 
pilot projects in this area are already being implemented. Moreover, Russian government, as 
well as the heads of enterprises themselves, are quite ready for the fact that cryptocurrency 
will soon become a common means of payment in this area. Moreover, foreign states such as 
USA, Japan, UAE, Germany, Switzerland and other are already using the practice of payment 
with cryptocurrencies, which allows smart contracts to be concluded and reduces the 
transaction period as much as possible. 
 
REFERENCES:

Certain Legislative Acts of the Russian Federation» of 31 July 2020 
2. Danilchuk E. «Mining in oil fields – the future of cryptocurrency mining?» [Electronic

Refinement of the geological model based on offshore drilling geosteering data 
Konovalenko Anton 
Student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas 
(National Research University) 
Scientific supervisor: Candidate of geological and mineralogical sciences Islamov A. 
 
ABSTRACT 
In this study, the results of drilling a well with a large deviation from the vertical 
using the innovative technology of ultra-deep section mapping were used. When drilling a 
well with a large deviation from the vertical, a detailed study of the area of the structural 
bridge was required. The significant area of the development site (5 x 2 km) and the block 
structure of the deposit required a non-standard approach to the methods of additional study 
of the area in order to obtain the most complete volume of reliable geological data that will 
allow us to characterize the field site in detail and update the geological model, thereby 
significantly reducing geological uncertainties.The analysis of drilling of a pilot horizontal 
shaft extending for more than 4000 m with the technology of ultra-deep mapping of the 
section through the target zone intersecting the strike of the main discontinuous faults should 
solve the problem of studying the geological structure of the site and justifying the planning 
of new wells. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Offshore, geosteering, geological model. 
 
Data on the drilling of an extended pilot horizontal shaft within the target interval 
with a control repeated opening of the roof of the Neokomsky super-tier and the water-
saturated reservoir zone below the Oil Water Contact (OWC) formed the basis of the updated 
geological model. 6 main discontinuous faults have been updated, the directions and 
amplitudes of displacement of tectonic blocks have been determined. 
Interpretation of drilling data with the GeoSphere device gives a complete 
understanding of the geological structure of the site (tool interpretation data are shown in 
Figure 1) and allows you to get an updated geological model of the field. The block structure 
of the structural bridge is confirmed. The assumption about the level of OWC at the level of 
the project, uniform for the entire field, is confirmed. The presence of watered zones around 
discontinuous violations was revealed. 
 
Figure 1. The result of interpretation of horizontal drilling data 

462 
 
According to the GeoSphere device, absolute marks of the OWC, roof and sole of the 
target interval were obtained. 
The study aimed at refining the geological model was based on the method of deep 
mapping of reservoir boundaries. Carrying out a horizontal shaft in the cross of faults of the 
block structure served as part of a detailed study of the geological structure of the deposit, 
especially in the case of complex geology and tectonic disturbances.

Control and Application Technologies for Drill String Vibrations and Shocks in Oil and Gas 
Wells 
Kosarev Mikhail Аleksandrovich 
Bachelor Student 
Gubkin Russian State University of Oil and Gas 
(National Research University) 
Scientific supervisor: Cand. of Sc., Assoc. Prof. Balitsky V.P. 
Academic adviser: Cand. of Sc., Assoc. Prof. Amitirova-Turgeneva D.L. 
 
ABSTRACT  
The paper considers the current methods of control and application 
technologies for 
drill string vibrations and shocks in oil and gas wells. Undeservedly little attention is 
paid to vibrations in modern drilling, as there is usually no information about them in the 
guidance documents, as well as when calculating the strength of the drill string. The practical 
significance of both harm and benefit with proper control is quite large. It is concluded that 
the highly technical future of drilling is seen in the introduction and cheapening of control and 
application technologies for the use of vibrations in drilling and the development of new ones. 
 
KEYWORDS  
Vibrations, shocks, ROP (Rate of Penetration), oscillations, BHA (Bottom Hole 
Assembly) 
 
Drill string vibrations and shocks (V&S) can limit the optimization of drilling 
performance, which is a key problem for trajectory optimizing, wellbore design, increasing 
drill tools life, rate of penetration, and intelligent drilling. The directional wells and other 
special trajectory drilling technologies are often used in deep water, deep wells, hard rock, 
and brittle shale formations. In drilling these complex wells, the cost caused by V&S 
increases. 
For many years, experts have been struggling with vibrations, considering them 
exclusively as a threat, but today in Russia, when the improvement of drilling 
processes in complex formations for the extraction of hard-to-recover hydrocarbon reserves is 
on the agenda, they can be used as an auxiliary force that will significantly increase drilling 
speeds, and therefore reduce their cost. 
Each control method is suitable for different conditions. The passive control method is 
given priority in addressing drill string V&S, as active and semiactive control methods are not 
yet mature. The control program of drill string V&S was completed to provide a reference for 
“harmless” drilling. Application technologies for the drill string V&S include improving 
ROP, controlling borehole trajectory, seismic while drilling, and reducing the friction of drill 
string.  
In order to further understand the evaluation and control technologies of drill string 
V&S, physical experiments should be established according to similar principles, which focus 
on the signal transmission rule along the drill string and the control system stability. The joint 
action system utilizing a variety of V&S absorbers should be established. The hybrid control 
technology for drill string V&S taking advantages of passive control, active control, and 
semiactive control needs to be developed.

Specifics of field development design and modeling for deposits of pre-Jurassic complex 
Krivilev Grigoriy Mikhailovich 
Student 
Gubkin university 
Scientific supervisors: Ph.D., assistant professor Khismatullina F.S.; Litvintseva E.V. 
 
ABSTRACT 
One of the topical directions for the development of oil and gas production in Western 
Siberia is the development of the pre-Jurassic complex deposits. The paper considers the 
specifics of the geological structure of volcanic deposits of the pre-Jurassic complex of one 
oilfield in the Khanty-Mansiysk Autonomous Okrug, provides the analysis of analogous 
deposits’ development, and presents the use of seismic data to build a new version of the 
geological model. 
The result of the conducted work is the development of methodological approaches to 
the development design and modeling of the pre-Jurassic complex sediments. 
 
KEYWORDS 
Volcanic deposits, felsic volcanic rocks, hard-to-recover reserves, pre-Jurassic 
complex 
 
To date, more than 100 hydrocarbon deposits have been discovered in the formations 
of the pre-Jurassic complex (DYuK) of Western Siberia, the initial geological reserves of oil, 
listed on the state balance, amount to about 400 million tons. The relevance of the 
development of these deposits is associated with the prospects for their classification as hard-
to-recover reserves. At the same time, at the moment there is no generally accepted approach 
to their development. 
Deposits of the DYuK on one of the oilffield on the territory of the Khanty-Mansiysk 
Autonomous Okrug (KhMAO) are represented by felsic volcanic rocks, unconformably 
overlying the basement. The sedimentation environment corresponds to the model of volcano 
formation, which causes a number of complicating factors: interlayering of lava flows 
resulting in a complex geometry, lateral variability of rock properties, the influence of flow 
propagation on fracturing. 
The complexities of designing and modeling the development of an such object are 
mainly associated with: 
• deposit boundary definition, due to the requirements of the state commission on 
reserves for the categorization of reserves; 
• insufficient knowledge of the object and the complexity of reservoir geometry 
forecasting; 
• a high degree of heterogeneity of reservoir properties vertically and horizontally. 
As part of the work, a version of the geological model of the object was created, based 
on the reservoir probability cube that was calculated with the involved 3D seismic data. The 
reservoir probability distribution was calculated by comparing the results of geophysical 
studies of wells with the cube of elastic parameters obtained as a result of elastic synchronous 
inversion. 
On the basis of the geological model, a hydrodynamic model of the DYuK deposits 
was built, development options were prepared, their optimization was performed, and 
technological indicators were calculated. 
The main results of the work are: 

466 
 
• development of methodological approaches to modeling and design of the 
development of DYuK deposits, taking into account the peculiarities of identifying the 
boundaries of deposits, due to the categorization of reserves; 
• creation of a geological and technological model using seismic data; 
• proposition of the best option for the development of DYuK deposits; 
• calculation of technological development indicators for the purpose of creating a 
design and technological document. 
 
REFERENCES: 
1. Gavura A.V., Khismatullina F.S., Antonov D.V., Kazakov K.V., Korepanova V.S. and 
others, Engineering analysis of field development, Moscow: Russian State University of Oil 
and Gas (NRU) named after I.M. Gubkina, 2017, 91 p. 
2. Gavura A.V., Sannikov I.N., Khismatullina F.S., Development Management Based on 
Reservoir Processes Modeling: Textbook, Moscow: Publishing Center of the Russian State 
University of Oil and Gas (NRU) named after I.M. Gubkin, 2017, 157 p.
